perturbation.original_text:
15.      The validity, construction and performance of this Agreement shall be
          governed by the laws of the State of New York.
perturbation.changed_text:
15.      The validity, construction and performance of this Agreement shall be
          governed by the laws of a state determined at the sole discretion of Lucent Technologies Inc.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause mandates that New York law governs the agreement. The modified clause introduces ambiguity by stating that the governing law will be determined at Lucent's discretion. This could be interpreted as a violation of fair contracting principles and create uncertainty about which jurisdiction's laws apply, making enforcement difficult. Ambiguity undermines the legal certainty that parties rely on when entering into a contract.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law - Principles of Certainty and Enforceability

perturbation.original_text:
11.      The Term of this Agreement will commence on the date above, and shall
          continue for a term of one (1) year. mPhase shall have the right to
          annually renew this agreement for a period of one year upon each annual
          expiration with the written consent of Lucent, which written consent
          shall not be unreasonably withheld. Either party wishing to terminate
          the Agreement must give written notice to the other party at least
          thirty (30) days prior to the desired date of termination.
perturbation.changed_text:
11.      The Term of this Agreement will commence on the date above, and shall
          continue for a term of one (1) year. mPhase shall have the right to
          annually renew this agreement for a period of one year upon each annual
          expiration with the written consent of Lucent. Either party wishing to terminate
          the Agreement must give written notice to the other party at least
          thirty (30) days prior to the desired date of termination.
perturbation.explanation: The original states Lucent cannot unreasonably withhold consent for renewal. By removing "which written consent shall not be unreasonably withheld," it grants Lucent the power to reject renewal without providing a reason, shifting contract power and potentially violating principles of good faith and fair dealing. This removal is an increased risk for mPhase.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law - Good Faith and Fair Dealing

perturbation.original_text: 13.      Neither Party shall be liable to the other for special, incidental, or          consequential damages, even if such Party has been advised of the          possibility of such damages.
perturbation.changed_text: 13.      Neither Party shall be liable to the other for special, incidental, or          consequential damages, unless the damages are a result of gross negligence or willful misconduct, in which case the liable party will provide a fruit basket.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause is a standard limitation of liability. The modified clause adds an exception for gross negligence or willful misconduct, but then imposes a frivolous remedy of a 'fruit basket'. This trivializes and undermines the potential for actual damages, creating a contradiction between acknowledging potential liability for serious misconduct and providing a nonsensical form of compensation. This renders the clause largely unenforceable, as a fruit basket does not constitute adequate compensation for gross negligence or willful misconduct.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law - Principles of Adequate Remedy and Enforceability
